texts.shortText: Previously incorrectly known as Argyrosomus hololepidotus, which remains a valid species, but occurs only off Madagascar.

Large, fairly elongated, silvery fish with a bronzy sheen, large scales, a wide fleshy-lipped mouth and a square tail. Black spot at base of pectoral fin and a row of silver spots along the lateral line.
Up to 180 cm total length and a mass of up to 75 kg.

Global: Has a widespread Indo-Pacific distribution in coastal waters from South Africa, up the east coast of Africa to Oman, Pakistan, India, China, Korea, Japan and Australia.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.

Small juveniles strongly associated with estuaries, larger ones also common in the surf zone. Adults occur mostly over soft substrata, but also in the vicinity of reefs or wrecks, ranges from the surf zone to a depth of 120 m. Reaches an age of at least 42 years.

Can produce loud sounds using muscles to vibrate the gas-filled swim bladder (hence the alternative common group name of drums or croakers) â€“ these sound probably associated with spawning behaviour.

A very important recreational and commercial fishery species, not only in South Africa, but also in Australia, where known as mulloway. Both stocks overfished.
Juveniles feed on small crustaceans, such as copepods and mysids. Adults feed on fish, shrimp and squid.

Females mature only at a length of about 110 cm at an age of 6 years and males at 92-100 cm and an age of 5 years. Spawn on inshore reefs at night. In the western Cape the spawning season is October to January, but the bulk of the population spawn in KZN in August to November.

Easily confused with the very similar Silver kob A. inodorus (indeed that species was only recognised and described in 1995). The main distinguishing factors are that the Silver kob has a longer, narrower peduncle to the tail and a longer pectoral fin. Also similar to Squaretail kob A. thorpei, but that species only occurs from Algoa Bay eastwards.
